rationale: Prostaglandin analogs remodel the ciliary muscle extracellular matrix, enhancing uveoscleral outflow.

text: Which acute symptom complex is most consistent with angle-closure crisis?
rationale: Acute angle-closure causes rapid IOP elevation with corneal edema, blurred vision, and a mid-dilated nonreactive pupil.
choices: Severe ocular pain, halos, mid-dilated fixed pupil, corneal edema

text: Which finding differentiates secondary open-angle glaucoma due to pseudoexfoliation?
rationale: Pseudoexfoliation deposits fibrillar material on the lens and TM, increasing outflow resistance and trabecular pigmentation.
choices: Flaky material on lens capsule and trabecular pigmentation

text: Which inherited condition is characterized by abnormal anterior chamber angle development in infancy?
rationale: Primary congenital glaucoma results from maldevelopment of the trabecular meshwork and Schlemm's canal, causing high IOP in infancy.

text: Which surgical procedure creates a new fistula from the anterior chamber to the subconjunctival space to enhance outflow?
rationale: Trabeculectomy forms a guarded filtration bleb to divert aqueous from the AC to the subconjunctival space, lowering IOP.

text: Which optic nerve head feature is most specific for glaucomatous damage rather than physiologic cupping?
rationale: Glaucoma causes localized rim loss that violates the ISNT rule (Inferior > Superior > Nasal > Temporal rim thickness).
choices: Notching of the neuroretinal rim violating the ISNT rule
Large but symmetric cup in both eyes
Pink neuroretinal rim with small cup

text: A patient presents with sudden severe eye pain after hammering metal. What is the most appropriate first diagnostic step?
rationale: CT is preferred to detect metallic foreign bodies; MRI is contraindicated because of risk of magnetic migration.
choices: CT scan of the orbits without contrast
MRI of the brain and orbits

text: Which finding best differentiates an open-globe injury from a superficial laceration?
rationale: A positive Seidel test confirms aqueous leakage from a full-thickness defect consistent with an open globe.
choices: Positive Seidel sign with leaking aqueous

text: In orbital floor fracture, diplopia occurs most commonly due to entrapment of which muscle?
rationale: The inferior rectus lies adjacent to the thin orbital floor and can become trapped, causing limitation of upgaze and diplopia.

text: A patient with blunt trauma shows blood layering in the anterior chamber. Which complication must be closely monitored?
rationale: Rebleeding and trabecular obstruction by RBCs can elevate IOP; daily monitoring is essential.
choices: Secondary IOP spike from trabecular blockage

text: Which sign is most concerning for orbital compartment syndrome after trauma?
rationale: Retrobulbar hemorrhage causing tense orbit and decreased vision is an emergency; lateral canthotomy/cantholysis is indicated.
choices: Proptosis with tight lids and decreased vision

text: Chemical alkali injuries damage the cornea primarily by which mechanism?
rationale: Alkali causes liquefactive necrosis and penetrates rapidly, destroying collagen and limbal stem cells.
choices: Saponification of cell membranes and deep tissue penetration
Coagulation necrosis with surface barrier formation

text: Which immediate management step takes precedence in chemical ocular burns?
rationale: Prompt irrigation with any available isotonic fluid to normalize pH prevents further chemical penetration and tissue loss.
choices: Copious irrigation until physiologic pH is achieved

text: A 65-year-old with temporal headache and jaw claudication presents with sudden monocular vision loss. Which laboratory test is most urgent?
rationale: GCA threatens the fellow eye; ESR and CRP are critical for rapid diagnosis before starting systemic corticosteroids.
choices: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP)

text: After a blow-out fracture, the globe appears sunken with enophthalmos. Which anatomic defect explains this finding?
rationale: Orbital floor fracture allows herniation of orbital contents into the maxillary sinus, reducing intraorbital volume and producing enophthalmos.
choices: Loss of orbital volume due to herniation of fat into maxillary sinus
Superior wall collapse into frontal sinus
Medial wall fracture into ethmoid cells

text: Which finding indicates optic nerve avulsion following severe blunt ocular trauma?
rationale: Optic nerve avulsion causes immediate, irreversible vision loss with absent APD and a normal-appearing anterior segment.
choices: Profound vision loss with absent afferent pupillary response but normal-appearing globe
Optic disc swelling with pain on movement
Mild field defect with normal vision

text: Which autonomic receptor subtype most directly mediates pupillary dilation via the iris dilator muscle?
condition: Lens / Cataract / IOL / Pre- & Post-Op Care
rationale: Iris dilator contraction is driven by sympathetic α1 stimulation.

text: Which vitamin is essential for rhodopsin regeneration and night vision?
rationale: 11-cis-retinal (vitamin A derivative) recombines with opsin to form rhodopsin.

text: Which systemic condition classically causes granulomatous anterior uveitis with elevated ACE and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy?
rationale: Noncaseating granulomas in sarcoid trigger granulomatous ocular inflammation.

text: Ethambutol toxicity most typically presents with which ocular finding?
rationale: Ethambutol optic neuropathy affects papillomacular bundle with color loss.
choices: Bilateral cecocentral scotomas and red-green dyschromatopsia
Arcuate field loss with normal color vision

text: Which antimalarial dosing threshold minimizes risk of hydroxychloroquine maculopathy?
rationale: Current guidance uses ACTUAL body weight with ≤5 mg/kg/day to lower risk.

text: Which systemic medication can precipitate acute myopic shift and secondary angle closure from choroidal effusions?
rationale: Topiramate can cause uveal effusion with forward movement of the lens-iris diaphragm.

text: Tamoxifen is most associated with which ocular toxicity?
rationale: Long-term tamoxifen can cause crystalline deposits and macular edema.

text: Amiodarone most commonly produces which ocular change?
rationale: Cationic amphiphilic drugs like amiodarone cause corneal verticillata.

text: Which systemic antibiotic is relatively safe in pregnancy for ocular infections?
rationale: Penicillins and most cephalosporins are generally considered safe; tetracyclines are avoided.

text: Which endocrine disease leads to fluctuating diplopia, lid retraction, and restrictive strabismus due to extraocular muscle fibrosis?
rationale: Autoimmune inflammation targets EOMs, especially the inferior rectus.

text: In diabetes mellitus, which mechanism most directly causes diabetic macular edema?
rationale: Pericyte loss and endothelial dysfunction disrupt tight junctions, causing edema.
choices: Breakdown of inner blood-retinal barrier with capillary leakage

text: Giant cell arteritis threatens vision primarily by ischemia of which structure?
rationale: Arteritic AION results from PCA involvement; urgent steroids are vision-saving.
choices: Posterior ciliary arteries supplying the optic nerve head

text: Which two labs are most immediately useful when suspecting giant cell arteritis?
rationale: Both ESR and CRP typically elevate and guide urgent treatment.

text: Which HIV-related opportunistic infection most commonly causes necrotizing retinitis with granular borders and hemorrhage?
rationale: CMV causes fulminant necrotizing retinitis in advanced immunosuppression.

text: Which systemic drug interaction increases INR/bleeding risk with warfarin and may present with subconjunctival hemorrhages?
rationale: CYP inhibition by macrolides/azoles elevates warfarin effect.

text: Which inherited hemoglobinopathy increases risk of IOP spikes and optic nerve damage with hyphema?
rationale: Sickling impedes trabecular outflow; avoid systemic CAIs which acidify blood.

text: Which systemic antibiotic class should be avoided in children due to risk of tooth discoloration and bone effects?
rationale: Tetracyclines chelate calcium and affect developing teeth/bone.

text: Which neurologic disease most commonly presents with painful unilateral optic neuritis in young adults?
rationale: Optic neuritis is tightly linked to demyelinating disease such as MS.

text: Which test confirms neurosyphilis in a patient with uveitis and positive treponemal screening?
rationale: CSF VDRL supports neurosyphilis; treat with IV penicillin.

text: Which systemic drug is a strong risk for IFIS (intraoperative floppy iris syndrome)?
rationale: α1A blockade affects iris dilator tone; alert the surgeon.

text: Which cardiac medication class can cause xanthopsia (yellow vision) and dyschromatopsia?
condition: Lens / Cataract / IOL / Pre- & Post-Op Care
rationale: Digoxin toxicity produces color vision changes including yellow tinges.

text: Which systemic antifungal used for onychomycosis can cause optic neuritis and should prompt ocular review if vision symptoms arise?
rationale: Voriconazole has known neuro-ocular toxicities at therapeutic levels.

text: Which vitamin deficiency is associated with Bitot spots and xerophthalmia?
rationale: Vitamin A deficiency impairs goblet cells and epithelial health.

text: Which systemic antihypertensive is relatively contraindicated in asthmatics due to bronchospasm risk and can mask hypoglycemia?
condition: Lens / Cataract / IOL / Pre- & Post-Op Care
rationale: β2 blockade provokes bronchospasm; β-blockers also blunt hypoglycemic symptoms.

text: Which systemic diuretic is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used to lower IOP but is cautioned in sickle cell disease?
rationale: Systemic CAIs acidify blood and can promote sickling; use caution.

text: Interferon-α therapy for hepatitis can cause which retinal change?
rationale: Microvascular ischemia manifests with CWS and hemorrhages.
choices: Cotton-wool spots and retinal hemorrhages (interferon retinopathy)

text: Linezolid prolonged therapy is associated with which neuro-ophthalmic complication?
rationale: Mitochondrial toxicity can lead to optic neuropathy after weeks of therapy.
choices: Optic neuropathy with color vision loss

text: Which systemic disease is most associated with episcleritis that blanches with phenylephrine and is often benign?
rationale: Episcleritis frequently accompanies IBD, RA, and other autoimmune conditions.

text: Wilson disease can show which distinctive corneal sign due to copper deposition?
rationale: Copper deposits at Descemet's periphery produce a golden-brown ring.

text: Which systemic medication can exacerbate dry eye by reducing aqueous secretion through anticholinergic effects?
rationale: Anticholinergic burden reduces lacrimation and salivation.

text: Which vitamin toxicity can cause pseudotumor cerebri (IIH) symptoms including papilledema?
rationale: Hypervitaminosis A is a known trigger for IIH.

text: Which endocrine disorder is most associated with bitemporal hemianopia from chiasmal compression?
rationale: Pituitary macroadenomas compress decussating nasal fibers at the chiasm.

text: Sildenafil and related PDE-5 inhibitors have been associated (rarely) with which optic event?
rationale: An association with NAION is reported; counsel patients with crowded discs and vascular risk.

text: Which systemic condition most classically causes salt-and-pepper fundus changes?
rationale: Congenital rubella syndrome may show mottled RPE (salt-and-pepper).

text: Which blood dyscrasia increases risk for retinal vein occlusion and should be considered in young patients?
rationale: Inherited thrombophilias predispose to venous occlusive disease.

text: Which systemic antitubercular regimen component is most associated with optic neuropathy risk?
rationale: Ethambutol dose and duration correlate with optic neuropathy risk.

text: Which autoimmune disease is most associated with peripheral ulcerative keratitis (PUK) and scleritis?
rationale: RA vasculitis can cause PUK and necrotizing scleritis.

text: Which systemic lipid disorder classically produces a corneal arcus at a young age?
rationale: Early arcus in patients <40 suggests significant hypercholesterolemia.

text: Which antibiotic pair is preferred for classic toxoplasma chorioretinitis?
rationale: Standard therapy combines folate antagonists plus leucovorin rescue.

text: Which systemic medication commonly causes whorl keratopathy besides amiodarone?
rationale: Chloroquine and other cationic amphiphiles cause verticillata.

text: Which neurologic autoimmune disorder causes fatigable ptosis and diplopia with positive ice-pack test?
rationale: MG targets postsynaptic ACh receptors; ocular symptoms are common.

text: Which endocrine disorder is associated with cotton-wool spots, microaneurysms, and neovascularization?
rationale: Chronic hyperglycemia damages capillaries leading to DR.

text: Which systemic antihypertensive medication can cause conjunctival hyperemia as a common side effect when used topically for glaucoma analogs?
rationale: Topical PGAs commonly cause redness, lash growth, and periorbitopathy.

text: Which neurologic condition presents with increased ICP, papilledema, headache, and transient visual obscurations, commonly in young obese females?
rationale: IIH (pseudotumor) features elevated opening pressure with normal imaging.

text: Which thyroid medication overdose can cause lid lag and stare with sympathetic overactivity signs?
rationale: Excess thyroid hormone increases sympathetic tone causing lid retraction/lag.

text: Which systemic malignancy is notorious for choroidal metastasis presenting as creamy subretinal lesions?
rationale: Breast and lung are the most common sources to the choroid.

text: Which connective tissue disorder is associated with lens subluxation and increased axial length?
rationale: Fibrillin-1 defects lead to ectopia lentis (superotemporal).

text: Which systemic drug is contraindicated in pregnancy and can cause fetal renal anomalies and skull defects?
rationale: ACE inhibitors/ARBs are teratogenic (especially 2nd/3rd trimesters).

text: Which autoimmune disease classically produces dry eye with parotid enlargement and positive anti-Ro/SSA?
rationale: Lacrimal and salivary gland infiltration causes aqueous-deficient dry eye.

text: Which systemic agent increases uveoscleral outflow when used as an oral prodrug for glaucoma is NOT used; instead, which topical analogs are standard?
rationale: Glaucoma therapy relies on topical PGAs to remodel ciliary muscle ECM.

text: Which systemic vasculitis is strongly linked with HLA-B27 and can cause recurrent acute anterior uveitis?
rationale: HLA-B27 spondyloarthropathies commonly have AAU flares.

text: Which systemic antiplatelet/anticoagulant combination raises risk of ocular hemorrhage during intravitreal injections?
rationale: Combined anticoagulation/antiplatelet therapy increases bleeding risk.

text: Which systemic disorder is associated with Lisch nodules on the iris and optic pathway gliomas?
rationale: NF1 shows café-au-lait macules, neurofibromas, iris hamartomas.

text: Which hepatic disease causes conjunctival and scleral icterus due to bilirubin deposition?
rationale: Elevated bilirubin stains elastin-rich tissues including sclera.

text: Which pulmonary disease therapy can cause raised IOP and posterior subcapsular cataracts with chronic use?
rationale: Steroids increase IOP in responders and predispose to PSC cataracts.

text: Which renal disease finding is associated with cotton-wool spots due to hypertension?
rationale: Chronic HTN causes arteriolar narrowing, CWS, and hemorrhages.
choices: Hypertensive retinopathy from chronic kidney disease
Polycystic kidney disease never shows this

text: Which endocrine emergency presents with Kussmaul respirations, dehydration, and blurred vision from hyperosmolarity?
rationale: DKA features acidosis and marked hyperglycemia causing lens swelling and refractive shifts.

text: Which malignancy is associated with Roth spots (white-centered retinal hemorrhages) due to septic emboli?
rationale: Roth spots occur in endocarditis from immune complex vasculitis and emboli.

text: Which neurologic infectious disease causes Argyll Robertson pupils (light-near dissociation)?
rationale: AR pupils accommodate but do not react to light; classic for neurosyphilis.

text: Which systemic cancer therapy is most associated with MEK-inhibitor retinopathy (SRF at the macula)?
rationale: MEK inhibitors can produce reversible serous maculopathy.

text: Which neurologic channelopathy causes night blindness and progressive constricted fields with bone-spicule pigmentation?
rationale: RP features rod dysfunction first with nyctalopia and mid-peripheral scotomas.

text: Which hematologic malignancy can cause hyperviscosity retinopathy with dilated tortuous veins and hemorrhages?
rationale: IgM paraproteinemia increases serum viscosity causing retinal changes.

text: Which endocrine therapy can cause color vision changes and optic neuritis-like picture (rare)?
rationale: Tamoxifen has multiple ocular toxicities beyond crystalline maculopathy.

text: Which systemic antibiotics are most associated with risk of tendinopathy and may precipitate uveitis (rare reports)?
rationale: FQs carry boxed warning for tendons; uveitis is rare but reported.

text: Which systemic immunotherapy can produce uveitis and serous retinal detachments as an adverse event?
rationale: Immune checkpoint inhibitors can cause ocular irAEs including uveitis and CSR-like changes.

text: Which systemic deficiency state causes optic neuropathy with central scotomas and anemia?
rationale: B12 deficiency can produce retrobulbar optic neuropathy and megaloblastic anemia.

text: Which systemic pediatric tumor is associated with leukocoria and requires urgent evaluation?
rationale: Leukocoria in a child is RB until proven otherwise.

text: Which systemic autoimmune disease shows a malar rash and can cause cotton-wool spots and vaso-occlusive retinopathy?
rationale: Immune complex vasculitis in SLE produces retinal ischemia and hemorrhages.

text: Which systemic metabolic disorder classically causes cherry-red spot at the macula in infants?
rationale: GM2 gangliosidosis spares foveal RPE, creating a red spot against pale retina.

text: Which systemic analgesic is contraindicated with narrow-angle glaucoma due to anticholinergic effects exacerbating angle closure?
rationale: Anticholinergic/antihistaminic agents may dilate pupils and precipitate closure in susceptible angles.

text: Which systemic disease produces Langerhans cell histiocytosis with possible orbital masses and proptosis in children?
rationale: LCH can involve orbit causing bone lesions and proptosis.

text: Which vitamin deficiency causes perifollicular hemorrhages and delayed wound healing that may worsen subconjunctival hemorrhages?
rationale: Ascorbate is needed for collagen crosslinking; deficiency weakens vessels.

text: Which systemic endocrine therapy can cause increased IOP and open-angle glaucoma risk with chronic use?
rationale: Steroid responders develop outflow resistance at the TM.

text: Which neurologic/paraneoplastic syndrome causes rapid ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and areflexia following infection?
rationale: Miller Fisher (anti-GQ1b) presents with ophthalmoplegia and ataxia.

text: Which systemic endocrine abnormality causes thickened extraocular muscles sparing tendons on imaging?
rationale: TED shows fusiform EOM enlargement with tendon sparing.

text: Which systemic drug is safest for treating acute bacterial sinusitis in a pregnant patient with preseptal cellulitis risk?
rationale: β-lactams are generally safe; tetracyclines, TMP-SMX (early), and FQs are avoided.

text: Which systemic immunosuppressant blocks calcineurin to reduce IL-2 transcription and is used in transplant patients with possible ocular side effects (e.g., tremor, neurotoxicity)?
rationale: Tacrolimus is a calcineurin inhibitor; monitor for neuro- and nephrotoxicity.

text: Which systemic cancer in men commonly metastasizes to the choroid causing amelanotic lesions?
rationale: Breast (women) and lung (men/women) are top sources of choroidal mets.

text: Which systemic mitochondrial disease presents with painless central vision loss in young men and temporal disc pallor?
rationale: LHON affects papillomacular bundle due to mitochondrial mutations.

text: Which systemic endocrine disorder is linked to central serous chorioretinopathy through cortisol excess?
rationale: Endogenous or exogenous steroids increase CSC risk.

text: Which systemic medication class is most likely to precipitate angle closure by pupillary block through mydriasis?
rationale: Mydriasis in narrow angles can obstruct trabecular outflow.

text: Which systemic autoimmune blistering disease shows conjunctival scarring and symblepharon risk?
rationale: Autoantibodies to basement membrane cause cicatrization.

text: Which systemic bone medication has been associated with scleritis and uveitis (rare) and requires cessation if inflammation occurs?
rationale: Bisphosphonates have rare ocular inflammatory adverse effects.

text: Which systemic nutritional deficiency can cause nystagmus, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia (Wernicke encephalopathy)?
rationale: B1 deficiency (often alcoholism) causes acute neuro-ophthalmic signs.

text: Which systemic autoimmune disease presents with pannus formation and keratolysis leading to corneal melting?
rationale: RA-associated vasculitis at the periphery can cause PUK and melt.

text: Which systemic endocrine abnormality increases risk for nonarteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy?
rationale: OSA contributes to nocturnal hypotension and vascular dysregulation.

text: Which systemic supplement at very high doses can cause intracranial hypertension similar to vitamin A excess?
rationale: Vitamin A excess and tetracyclines are classic IIH triggers.
choices: Tetracyclines (drug, not supplement) and high vitamin A; high B6 causes neuropathy instead

text: Which systemic enzyme deficiency causes angiokeratomas, corneal verticillata, and painful neuropathy?
rationale: Fabry produces whorl keratopathy and systemic vasculopathy.
